paper_metadata.title: MAIN TEXT
paper_metadata.extraction_summary: The paper discusses the R534C mutation in the KCNH2 gene associated with type 2 long QT syndrome, detailing its effects on cardiomyocytes derived from induced pluripotent stem cells.

patients.demographics: female, 44 years old; male, 17 years old

individual_records.evidence_sentence: PBMNC were isolated from a healthy male donor (24 years old, CTRL-iPSC) and 2 donors with a diagnosis of familial LQTS2 with a heterozygous R534C mutation (female, 44 years old, LQTS2-iPSC1; and male, 17 years old, LQTS2-iPSC2).

PBMNC were isolated from a healthy male donor (24 years old, CTRL-iPSC) and 2 donors with a diagnosis of familial LQTS2 with a heterozygous R534C mutation (female, 44 years old, LQTS2-iPSC1; and male, 17 years old, LQTS2-iPSC2).

functional_data.summary: The R534C mutation leads to a channel trafficking defect to the plasma membrane, resulting in prolonged action potential duration in cardiomyocytes.

variants.segregation_data: The mutation segregates with disease in the two patients described.
variants.additional_notes: The study utilized patient-specific iPSC-derived cardiomyocytes to model the effects of the mutation.
key_quotes: Our findings suggest that the R534C mutation in KCNH2 leads to a channel trafficking defect to the plasma membrane.
We observed a significant prolongation of APD in cardiomyocytes derived from LQTS2 iPSC lines compared to CTRL-iPSC.

extraction_metadata.notes: All relevant data regarding the KCNH2 variant was extracted from the main text.
